thread.title: Today’s Top Supply Chain and Logistics News From - WSJ
thread.title_full: Today’s Top Supply Chain and Logistics News From WSJ - WSJ

author: Paul Page
title: Today’s Top Supply Chain and Logistics News From - WSJ
text:
0 COMMENTS Sign up: With one click, get this newsletter delivered to your inbox .
The top export from several U.S. ports this fall is air. WSJ Logistics Report’s Erica E. Phillips writes that the strong growth in empty containers at ports that have reported September figures highlights economic weakness around the world . Outbound ships from U.S. ports often carry large volumes of scrap material—such as metal and wastepaper—that feed industrial production in China. But as the Chinese economy has slowed and the dollar’s strength has driven a wider trade deficit here at home, the demand for those products has fallen. At ports such as Long Beach, the empties are far outpacing the loaded containers, a reflection of slipping U.S. exports that are sending the trade imbalance soaring.
The shift in U.S. energy consumption is hitting CSX Corp. CSX -2.33 % hard . The WSJ’s Anne Steele writes the freight railroad reported an 8.8% decline in revenue in the third quarter that was largely the result of falling fuel surcharges and the steep decline in coal volume . CSX still reported a $507 million profit in the September quarter, slightly behind the earnings from a year ago. But the railroad is managing a dropoff in coal demand that weighs more heavily on CSX than on other railroads. On average, rail companies earn about 15% of revenue from coal; for CSX, it is about 20%. With coal volume down 18% in the quarter as cheaper natural gas cuts into demand, the railroad is projecting $450 million less revenue from coal this year. That is a deeper drop than CSX projected only a month ago, and CSX says the coal headwinds will continue into next year.
Alibaba Group Holding Ltd. BABA -0.88 % is looking outside China for its growth. The WSJ’s Gillian Wong writes that the e-commerce giant will soon open offices in Italy, France and Germany as the company ramps up international expansion . It’s an important step since Alibaba’s home market in China is unsteady and the company is trying to look more like a thoroughly global player. Chief Executive Daniel Zhang said that for this year’s discount Singles Day festival on Nov. 11—China’s biggest online sales day—Alibaba will promote products from other countries to Chinese consumers as well as Chinese products to overseas buyers. With the rate of sales growth in China slowing, those overseas markets appear to be Alibaba’s best bet for the kind of scale the company is seeking.
SUPPLY CHAIN STRATEGIES ENLARGE Photo: Bloomberg News The $104.2 billion Anheuser-Busch InBev NV pending takeover of SABMiller SBMRY 5.59 % PLC will set a new standard for scale in mergers and for combining global supply chains. The WSJ’s Tripp Mickle writes the deal announced on Tuesday will reshuffle the global beer industry and set the stage for higher beer prices world-wide .It would give AB InBev a dominant presence on every major continent and make it the world’s largest brewer with an estimated 28.4% market share after divestitures with some $64 billion in revenue. The acquisition reflects the strategy that also marks consolidation in the logistics market: with growth slowing, a big purchase is the easiest way to add new revenue. Beer consumption is falling in developed markets but SABMiller has operations across Africa, and AB InBev is likely to invest in production and distribution on the continent while it manages declining production in the U.S.
QUOTABLE
‘ Africa and Latin America are on fire. ’
—HSBC analyst Carlos Laboy on SABMiller’s drinks business.
IN OTHER NEWS Oil prices retreated Tuesday as traders absorbed pessimistic forecasts about lingering oversupply. (WSJ)
China exports fell 3.7% in September while imports plunged 20.4%. (WSJ)
China’s auto sales increased in September after three months of declines. (WSJ)
Mark Yeager resigned from the Hub Group Inc. HUBG -3.70 % board, breaking entirely from the company founded by his father and run by his brother. (WSJ)
Ryder System Inc. R -9.28 % lowered its 2015 earnings guidance , citing in part fleet-management problems. (WSJ)
General Electric Co. will sell much of its commercial lending business to Wells Fargo & Co. (WSJ)
A shortage of construction workers is making it tough for home builders to take advantage of the strongest sales of new homes since the recession. (WSJ)
Singapore Airlines struck a deal with Airbus Group SE that will bring in new jets for extended nonstop flights. (WSJ)
Paypal says it will pay for the shipping of some returns during the holiday season. (CNN)
BNSF Railway has nearly completed adding double tracks to its lines between Los Angeles and Chicago. (Dallas Morning News)
Argentina is trying to expanding its mining and exporting of lithium . (Industry Week)
The warehouse vacancy rate in New Jersey dipped to the lowest level since the recession. (JOC)
A warehouse at the Port of Tianjin containing alcohol materials exploded but no injuries were reported. (AP)
DHL added 767 freighter service through Detroit to handle growing volume from auto makers and their suppliers. (Air Cargo News)
The truckload driver turnover rate grew in the second quarter , the American Trucking Associations said. (Logistics Management)
United Parcel Service Inc. UPS -1.06 % said it would add 41,000 postal codes to its global express service. (DC Velocity)
ABOUT US Paul Page is deputy editor of WSJ Logistics Report. Follow him at @PaulPage , and follow the entire WSJ Logistics Report team: @brianjbaskin , @lorettachao , @RWhelanWSJ and @EEPhillips_WSJ , and follow the WSJ Logistics Report on Twitter at @WSJLogistics .
